awd_titl_txt: Travel: Student Travel Support for 2024 IEEE Radio & Wireless Week (RWW)
awd_abstract_narration:
The IEEE Radio & Wireless Week (RWW) covers a broad range of emerging research topics in radio wireless technologies, from theory to practical implementation, from integrated chips to large-scale systems, from kilohertz (kHz) to terahertz (THz), and from communications to sensing and space applications. It is sponsored by the IEEE Microwave Theory and Technology Society, with technical co-sponsorships from the IEEE Antennas and Propagation Society, the IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Society, and the IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Society. The 19th annual IEEE RWW will be held in San Antonio, TX on January 21-26, 2024. To support the training of the next-generation scientists and engineers working on 6G Wireless, this NSF grant will provide travel support for 25 students to present their research papers at the conference and learn the cutting-edge research and development of wireless technologies, systems, and applications. The travel grants will be awarded competitively to graduate students from U.S. universities who will present their accepted papers at the conference. The awardees will be selected by a committee of the conference and the paper quality will be considered in the selection process. The proposed travel support will have long-term and broad impacts on the participating students' career developments and contribute to the U.S. STEM workforce development.

The IEEE RWW in 2024 consists of five co-located sub-conferences: Topical Conference on Power Amplifiers for Wireless and Radio Applications (PAWR), Topical Meeting on Silicon Monolithic Integrated Circuits in RF Systems (SiRF), Topical Conference on Wireless Sensors and Sensor Networks (WiSNet), Space Hardware and Radio Conference (SHaRC), and Radio and Wireless Symposium (RWS). Students attending the conference will learn about the latest state-of-the-art wireless technologies in these topical areas covering devices, integrated circuits, antennas, system architectures, and emerging applications such as 6G Wireless and space communications/sensing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 19th IEEE Radio & Wireless Week (RWW), held from January 21-24, 2024, in San Antonio, Texas, served as an important event for the wireless and microwave community, focusing on the latest advancements in wireless communication, systems, circuits, and device technologies. Sponsored by the IEEE Microwave Theory and Techniques Society (MTTS) and co-sponsored by the IEEE Antennas and Propagation Society (APS), IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Society (AESS), and the IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Society (GRSS), RWW2024 aimed to promote knowledge exchange and collaboration within this growing field.
Intellectual Merit:
The RWW2024 conference brought together researchers, industry experts, and students to discuss key developments in wireless communication and technology. One of the significant outcomes of this project was the financial support provided to undergraduate and graduate students from U.S. universities, enabling them to participate in the conference. Each student received travel support, which allowed them to present their research and gain exposure to leading-edge technologies and developments. The event comprised five co-located conferences, including the IEEE Topical Conference on Power Amplifiers for Wireless and Radio Applications (PAWR), the Topical Meeting on Silicon Monolithic Integrated Circuits in RF Systems (SiRF), IEEE Topical Conference on Wireless Sensors and Sensor Networks (WiSNet), IEEE Space Hardware and Radio Conference (SHaRC), and the Radio and Wireless Symposium (RWS). These conferences collectively covered a wide array of topics ranging from fundamental theories to practical implementations in various frequency ranges and application domains, from communication systems to sensing and space technologies.
The inclusion of these sub-conferences at RWW2024 played a crucial role in encouraging cross-disciplinary collaboration and expanding the boundaries of existing research. Through technical sessions and panel discussions, the conference facilitated in-depth knowledge sharing on the latest findings in wireless communication and related technologies. The resulting outcomes are expected to advance the development of radio and wireless systems and foster new innovations across multiple fields.
Broader Impacts:
The RWW2024 conference emphasized the importance of inclusivity and diversity in advancing wireless communication technologies. By encouraging underrepresented minority groups and females to attend and present their research, the conference promoted a more diverse and inclusive academic environment. The gathering also provided a valuable educational platform for students, offering a range of activities such as oral and poster sessions, exhibitions, and talks by leading experts in various areas of radio wireless technologies.
These opportunities allowed students to engage with industry and academic professionals, fostering discussions that exposed them to cutting-edge technologies and critical developments in their fields. This exposure was instrumental in positioning students for future career opportunities in the wireless industry and academia. Furthermore, the conference’s focus on key enabling technologies across multiple domains ensured that attendees gained insights into emerging trends and advancements in RF/microwave/mm-wave/THz-related areas.
In conclusion, the RWW2024 conference successfully achieved its goal of supporting the next generation of scholars and engineers working in the field of wireless communication. By providing financial support for student participation and creating an environment for interdisciplinary collaboration and knowledge exchange, the project contributed to both the intellectual advancement of wireless technologies and the broader professional development of students and underrepresented groups. This initiative is expected to have a lasting impact on the growth and evolution of wireless communication and related technologies, ultimately benefiting the broader scientific and engineering communities.
